results.title: Elizabethan express
results.creator_credit: Tony Thompson, Edgar H. Anstey and British Transport Films
results.brief_description: From King’s Cross Station, London, to Waverley Station, Edinburgh, is 393 miles. The Elizabethan - a summertime express - does this journey in six and a half hours non-stop - the longest daily non-stop run in the world to be timed at over 60 mph in 1954. This film is about one of those runs and the people behind the service.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tony Thompson, Edgar H. Anstey and British Transport Films

results.title: Elizabethan England
results.creator_credit: W. Hugh Baddeley, Clement W. Bending and Gateway Film Productions
results.brief_description: Based on a horseback journey through towns, villages and open country, this film provides a central theme around which sequences are woven illustrating costumes, furniture, architecture, farming and other features of life during the first Elizabethan period. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: W. Hugh Baddeley, Clement W. Bending and Gateway Film Productions

results.title: Elizabeth: visual impairment
results.brief_description: From the “People you’d like to know” series this episode focuses on a young girl with impaired sight, showing how she has learnt to cope with her disability and adjusted to her surroundings. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Elizabeth: the queen who shaped an age
results.creator_credit: John Paddy Carstairs, Helen Jean Secondari, John H. Secondari, Learning Corporation of America and John H Secondari Productions
results.brief_description: This dramatic recreation of the reign of Elizabeth I of England is a study of political power used for noble ends. Elizabeth inherited a troubled and divided country. A Protestant ruler in a predominantly Protestant country, she held out as long as she could against Parliament’s desire to pass anti-Catholic laws. When she discovered there was a plot against her life, Elizabeth signed the execution order against her cousin, Mary, Queen of Scots even though she feared this would divide England firmly into two camps - Protestants and Catholics. Elizabeth I forged a great nation - a military power second to none, a glorious home for the arts, commerce and exploration, and a symbol of the Renaissance belief in the worth of man. Cast: Frances Cuka as Elizabeth I. Filmed at Hever Castle, Kent, England. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Elizabeth Riddell
results.creator_credit: John Erichsen, Australia Council and Royce Smeal Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II”.
Elizabeth Riddell came to Australia from New Zealand when she was eighteen. She recalls the community of artists and writers in Sydney in the 1930’s and her early experiences as a journalist. During the Second World War Riddell reported from North America and travelled through Europe. On her return to Australia, her long autobiographical poem was published. Riddell discusses the conflict between the demands of her career and her desire to write poetry. She speaks about the discipline of writing and the state of contemporary Australian literature.

results.title: Elizabeth R.
results.brief_description: Glenda Jackson received world-wide acclaim for her brilliant portrayal of Queen Elizabeth the Ist. The series begins just prior to Elizabeth’s ascension to the throne and continues to her death in 1603. The episodes deal with historical events such as the Armada, Mary Queen of Scots, the beheading of Essex, the plight over the Succession and her decision to remain unmarried. The series is well scripted, costumed and has an excellent cast.

results.title: Elizabeth Maconchy
results.creator_credit: Margaret Williams, Fiz Oliver and Arbor Films
results.brief_description: A biographical documentary about classical music composer, Elizabeth Maconchy. Born in 1907, she began writing music at the age of 6 and continued to do so, succeeding in an area that, in the early to middle 20th century, was almost entirely a male preserve. This film features some of her works and includes interviews with people who have been associated with her.

results.title: Elizabeth Macarthur: a great pioneer
results.brief_description: Elizabeth Macarthur made an enormous contribution to the establishment of Australia’s wool industry, but is usually not recognised in the history books. Each time her husband, John, returned to England (for four years and later for eight years) Elizabeth was left to breed the sheep, produce the wool, manage convicts, bushfires and Aboriginal uprisings, run a profitable farm, act as accountant and be a mother to their six children.

results.title: Elizabeth Jolley
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers III”.
One of Australia’s most popular and acclaimed novelists, Elizabeth Jolley recalls her childhood and the influence of her Quaker upbringing in the industrial north of England. Jolley emigrated to Western Australia with her husband and three children and worked as a cleaner and travelling saleswoman to support her writing. Despite twenty years of rejection slips her first book of short fiction, “Five Acre Virgin and Other Stories” was eventually published in 1976. Another five books were released in the following six years and her radio plays were produced by both the ABC and the BBC World Service. Jolley asserts the importance of imagination over experience in her creative life and her belief in the value of regional fiction. Research and interview: James Murdoch.

group.title: Australia Council archival film series: writers III

results.title: Elizabeth
results.creator_credit: Shekhar Kapur, Tim Bevan, Eric Fellner, Alison Owen and Working Title Films
results.brief_description: Elizabeth begins during the tense period before Elizabeth I became Queen of England. She is a young vivacious girl thrust suddenly into the machiavellian world of politics when she is tried for treason at the age of 21. Surviving this she becomes Queen, and the film charts the beginning of her reign as she struggles to learn the skills of a monarch. Cate Blanchett is amazing as a young woman who slowly casts off her youth and becomes the legendary Virgin Queen that ruled the Elizabethan age. Shekhar Kapur’s film manages to be both entertaining and historically insightful. Lavish costumes and an excellent cast make this compelling viewing. The cast also includes Joseph Fiennes as Elizabeth’s lover Lord Robert Dudley, Richard Attenborough as Sir William Cecil, and Geoffrey Rush as her political adviser Sir Francis Walsingham. (Awards: Cate Blanchett won the 1998 Golden Globe for Best Actress in a Drama, and “Elizabeth” won the 1998 Academy Award for Best Makeup)
